text:
Sawaddee ka welcome to the Halloween special 
of hot thai kitchen and if you're not watching

this on Halloween well ignore the costume anyways 
so people are carving pumpkins all over town so I

thought it would be appropriate for me to show 
you a traditional Thai dessert that involves a

little bit of a pumpkin carving skill and so 
we're making something called Sankaya faktong

here's the breakdown of the word sankaya is 
a coconut custard and faktong means pumpkin

and in Thailand it actually refers to a kabocha 
squash which is the only kind of pumpkin we have

so we're going to make the coconut custard fill 
the carve out the pumpkin I'm going to refer to

this as a pumpkin from now on and then cook the 
custard in this pumpkin all right so let's take

a look at our ingredients so we've got 1 kabocha 
squash 1 cup of coconut milk 300 grams of palm

sugar 6 eggs plus 1 egg yolk half a teaspoon 
plus 1/8 of a teaspoon of salt 1 tablespoon of

rice flour and 1 pandan leaf ok so first we're 
going to carve out our pumpkin here and I should

probably take off my Bunny gloves and we're going 
to carve out the lid the square on top just go in

you can also use a another kind of squash you can 
use a sugar pumpkin like the one they used to make

pumpkin pie or you can use a red kuri squash ok 
so now the hard part is getting the lid out and

make sure all the corners are loose that nothing 
is kind of still stuck and think about kabocha

squash is it often does not come with a handle for 
you to pull it off so it's a bit of a struggle so

what I do is I just kind of take my knife and 
wiggle it to try to get it to come up there we

go oh come on you can do this da we're going to 
clean this up because we're going to use the lid

well at least eat it so just cut this out and then 
you're going to do what you normally do with your

pumpkin is to take a spoon sharp edges so thin 
spoons would be nice and hollow out all the seeds

okay and now you want to make sure you scrape out 
as much of the furry stuff inside as you can and

then rinse the pumpkin just because there's often 
loose furry stuff inside so just rinse it out to

get rid of any of the loose stuff that's up and 
now just going to let this sit on paper towel or

on a towel of some sort and just so that it don't 
dry out and now that that's done we're going to

make the custard we're just going to cook the palm 
sugar with the coconut milk just so that the sugar

is dissolved and I'm not going to pour in all the 
coconut milk I'll save some you'll see why in a

minute and oh the pandan leaves are also going in 
to infuse now you're just going to cook this until

the sugar dissolve no more no need to bring it to 
a boil in fact traditionally they don't even cook

this mixture but in Thailand what they use is 
the kind of palm sugar that's soft and sticky

and wet and it dissolves quite easily in liquid so 
what they do is they put everything in a big bowl

and just use their hand scrunch scrunch and the 
sugar will eventually dissolve and in the act of

scrunching the pandan leaves get agitated enough 
that it extracts that you can extract the flavors

through the mechanical action but we are using the 
hard type of palm sugar and the scrunching doesn't

this would work trust me I've tried and meanwhile 
while this is cooking what you want to have setup

is a steamer so I've got this big steamer here 
and we're going to cook our pumpkin in here so

it's a good idea while your thing is cooking to 
get some water in there and get it get it started

so that when our pumpkin is ready you don't have 
to wait for it to boil and all that stuff so while

you're here you know just being efficient okay 
so just bring this over and letting it chill out

here for a second while we get our other parts 
ready and I'm doing one extra egg yolk because

traditionally this recipe uses duck eggs which 
has a higher yolk to white ratio so I'm adding

one extra yolk just to mimic that because I can't 
find duck eggs here so that little bit of coconut

milk that we saved I'm just going to add it to 
a rice flour so that it mixes it dissolves it a

little bit because adding rice flour directly 
to the eggs usually leave annoying clumps and

the rice flour will actually help stabilize the 
custard because we're using coconut milk and as

you know coconut milk has a tendency to like if 
you've opened a can of coconut milk the fat will

float to the top and the watery part will stay 
down below and adding a little bit of starch will

actually help minimize that separation it will 
still separate so your cusses will have like kind

of two layers going which is completely that's 
what you are expecting but adding a little bit

of starch will help minimize that you don't have 
to go out and buy a rice flour for this if all

you have is all-purpose flour you can add a little 
less perhaps two tea spoons of all-purpose flour

for this don't forget your salt desert you're 
never good without salt okay so now this more

or less mixed up we're going to go in with our 
palm sugar coconut mixture so this shouldn't be

that hot because we didn't we didn't boil it or 
anything just to the sugar was mostly dissolved

but just in case we're going to slowly pour it 
in anyway and that the procedure if you notice

is exactly the same as you would make any kind 
of western-style custard creme brulee flan creme

caramel now this makes this is going to make more 
than I need for one pumpkin but I'm giving you

this recipe just because some people have bigger 
pumpkins and some people have smaller and so it's

always good to have extra rather than not enough 
to fill a pumpkin right so now we're going to

strain it just to make sure there are no clumps 
lumps of any rice flour sugar or anything in it

or any gloopy bits of egg yolk I mean egg whites 
now if you want to test it like if you decide to

change or change up the recipe you want to see 
how sweet this is maybe you want it more sweet

or whatever you can take a little bit and steam 
just a little bit in the bowl to taste it and

see if you like how it tastes that would be a way 
to do it okay now we're going to fill our pumpkin

but before we do that we're going to set it up 
in our steaming container so I could steam the

pumpkin just on its own in a steamer but these 
things have been known to crack as it seems so

when that happens the custard will come running 
out so putting it in if you have a bowl that

exactly the size of this pumpkin that'll work 
or you can put it in something bigger and then

put foil all around it which is what I'm going to 
do and the soyal will kind of help access support

for the pumpkin so it's not so if it does split 
it's not going to collapse all over the place

and you're going to fill it not all the way up 
because it will fluff up a little just when it

reaches the base of the pumpkin and also I should 
mention that some pumpkins have thicker flesh than

others so when you are buying the heavier it 
feels for its size that means the thicker it

is and also you want to pick a pumpkin that is 
has orange is dark green and has orange patches

around it because that is a sign that it is right 
if it's all green and there's no sign of orange

that means the pumpkin will be very young and it 
won't be it won't have a lot of flavor to it will

be very just not good so so here we are and that's 
it we're going to steam this and don't forget the

lid we're going to steam the lid along with it 
because we want to use it to close go into the

steamer now we're going to see this for about 
an hour so make sure there is enough water in

your steamer or it'll dry out and you'll burn 
your pot which I have done before and you could

also I'm guessing it's possible to do this in 
the oven although I'm not sure how long or what

temperature but I'm probably thinking something 
300 to 325 a low oven just like you would like

a cheesecake okay so the heat I'm putting it on 
medium heat not too high you want the the water

to be boiling but not so vigorously because the 
higher the heat the the custard will fluff up

too fast and it won't be as smooth so this the 
nature of this custard is not supposed to be

you know Burrell a smooth anyway but you want 
to kind of help it help it out a little bit by

not putting in too much heat so about 50 minutes 
to an hour and then we'll come and take it out

so I made this last night to show you because 
the the pumpkin needs to cool down and everything

before you cut it now I wanted to show you also 
that this one split usually it'll split if it

does at the natural groups of the pumpkin and 
that's why it's important that you support it

with something so when you bring this to a 
party you can bring it like this put the lid

back on and I already cut this yesterday and 
then the inside will look like that when you

serve it you just want to cut it into wedges 
and it's a good idea in between cuts to wipe

your knife this is standard also cake cutting 
procedure if you're cutting nice wedding cakes

or whatever it is it's always good to clean off 
your knife so that the next slice is nice and

clean and that's it this is our sang-hyuk tall 
you can also call it [ __ ] tong sleng - yeah

and reverse the order as you can see you 
can add there's a the top part is a little

different texture wise in the bottom part that's 
a natural separation if we didn't put the rice

flour in there to be a more distinct separation 
so a nice gradient like this is perfect and

also the skin is perfectly edible it's really 
soft and you don't have to eat it but you can

and it's probably really good for you too lots 
of nutrients so that's all for your Halloween

special I hope you enjoyed the show and if you 
did please subscribe and for the recipe you

can visit hot Thai kitchen calm and I will see 
you next time for your next delicious Thai meal
you
